Unfortunatley 15 hours of classes is a bit too little. I don't think that you already aquired a general understanding how the German language works. A tandem partner could only talk about a 'Guten Tag' and 'Hallo' with you. This won't help you much. In a year or so you'll have enough knowledge to try talking with a native. At least you won't have to look into a dictionary each time someone says something. This is frustrating over time.

We do not even know whether the man wants to learn Dutch or Deutsch, as both are equally possible. Which one is it, LegoDino?

I would mainly advise to watch television in the language you want to learn. This really helps the perception and is an easy way to learn expressions and how to use them.

Being Dutch (Netherlands) myself AND apart from speaking my native Dutch also speak English and German (Deutsch) I have some experience with the confusion. No idea where LegoDino is from, pretty much all Europeans know the difference. But, offense to the USA, most Americans don't have a clue.

Seriously, I've seen American tourists wandering through major cities with an English-German dictionary wondering why they couldn't translate the signs.

I could help, I speak German fairly well, but I don't speak much Dutch, so depending on what language you actually want to learn, I could be a asset or a Liability.
